The silence grew heavier, the shadows longer. I felt a pang of despair, a sense of failure gnawing at me. It was all so clear now - tomorrow's disaster, next week's scandal, all because tonight's classroom lay empty and silent.

**Text:**

The echo of the closing door seemed unnaturally loud, a stark contrast to the heavy silence that had fallen upon the room mere moments ago. The parent's words still hung in the air, like a thick, invisible fog that I couldn't quite shake off. "It's not working," they had said, their gaze avoiding mine, as if the very act of looking at me would cause them discomfort.

I watched them leave, their hands tightly clasped around Johnny's, his small frame trembling with barely suppressed sobs. The sight of him looking back at me, tear-streaked cheeks and all, would have been heart-wrenching under any other circumstance. But today, it only served to fuel the anger that was beginning to simmer within me.

How could they do this? I thought, my hands clenching instinctively into fists by my sides. How could they just uproot Johnny like that, without even giving him a chance to adjust? Didn't they know how hard I had worked with him? How much time and effort I had invested in helping him catch up?

I couldn't help but feel a sense of betrayal. After all, hadn't I done everything by the book? Hadn't I stayed after hours to tutor Johnny, had countless meetings with his parents to discuss his progress, or lack thereof? And now, they were just throwing it all away, blaming me for their son's struggles.

But no, that wasn't entirely fair. They hadn't explicitly blamed me. They had simply said "it's not working," a phrase that could mean anything and nothing at the same time. Yet, here I was, standing alone in an empty classroom, another one leaving me, another failure to add to my growing list.

I took a deep breath, trying to calm myself down. There was no use dwelling on what had happened. What mattered now was moving forward, finding a way to help Johnny from afar, even if his parents refused to see the value in my methods. I owed him that much, at least.

As I gathered my things and prepared to leave the classroom, I couldn't shake off the feeling of resentment that lingered within me. But I knew better than to act on it. After all, as a professional, it was my duty to rise above such emotions, to focus on what truly mattered: helping Johnny, no matter how difficult the path might be.

But even as I resolved to do just that, I couldn't help but wonder why some parents seemed so hell-bent on making our jobs harder than they already were. It wasn't like we didn't care about their children's well-being. We did. More than they would ever know. Yet, sometimes, it felt like no matter how hard we tried, there was always someone ready to point a finger at us, to blame us for everything that went wrong.

I sighed, shaking my head as I stepped out of the classroom, leaving behind another empty room filled with echoes of unspoken accusations and silent promises.
